title: Millionaires’ fight could see new house being demolished and moved 1ft to the left
text:
The houses are located on a WWII bomb site that was rebuilt as flats

A fight over a tiny strip of land could see a £3 million home have to be partially demolished and moved a foot to the left.

Tom and Helen Gueterbock accused Alex and Helen MacPhail of a land grab when they built a new home that they say went onto their territory by 12 inches.

They are now demanding that former City trader Mr MacPhail, must fill in his basement and move his house further away.

However, he denies encroaching on his neighbour’s land and the case has ended up in court.

Mr MacPhail’s home was built on the site of a 1940 German bomb blast in Henderson Road, Wandsworth.

The MacPhails wanted to return the piece of land to their original pre-war state (Picture: Google Street View)

The 1ft wide strip of land that is being fought over by the neighbours (Picture: Campion News)

He wanted to rebuild a period house that originally stood there, replacing a block of council flats that were built after World War Two.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Mr Gueterbock said the house is much closer than it should be and they only have a tiny passageway along the side of their home.

He only realised how close it actually was once the hoarding had come down after the house was built.

He also said the MacPhail’s basement goes under the passage, right up to their wall.

Most residents were in favour of the proposals when they were put forward, which would see the ‘out of character’ former council block replaced by three smart new townhouses, documents reveal.

As well as five bedrooms above ground level, the plans included space for a nanny’s room in the 88ft long basement area beneath.

The development’s neighbour wants the basement to be filled in and a wall to be moved 1ft to the left (Picture: Google Street View)

The Gueterbocks’ solicitor, Robert Page said: ‘The works ran between November 2015 and October 2018. But Mr and Mrs MacPhail went further than what was there before.

‘In between, they narrowed the alleyway above ground and they dug it out below, right up to the flank wall of Mr and Mrs Gueterbock’s house – a “land grab”.’

Mr Gueterbock, 50, wants an injunction requiring Mr MacPhail to fill in the basement and make the passageway wider again.

Mr MacPhail claims that the passageway between the two houses forms part of the title to his property.

When the bombsite was compulsorily purchased by the council in 1949, it included the entirety of the passageway, he insists.

Advertisement

Advertisement

In his defence to his neighbours’ claim, his barrister Sebastian Kokelaar says the Gueterbocks originally objected to the planning application for the MacPhail house.

They had concerns over the boundary line, a basement lighting grate in the alley floor, and their access for bikes and pushchairs down the side of the house.

But after negotiations, they had withdrawn their objection, which he says meant they effectively agreed that the gap between the houses was part of what is now the MacPhail property. The boundary between them runs along the side of the Gueterbocks’ house, he says.

He said: ‘They stood by and allowed the development to proceed, knowing that the company and the MacPhails believed – mistakenly, on the Gueterbocks’ case – that the plans submitted to the council in support of the planning application correctly showed the location of the boundary.

‘If, which is denied, the Gueterbocks are the legal owners of the western half of the passageway, it would be unconscionable for them now to insist on their rights of ownership.’

In court, the MacPhails’ solicitor, Thomas West, said any court order requiring the basement or outer wall of the house to be moved would effectively mean ‘partial demolition of a completed building’.

The case appeared in court for a brief preliminary hearing in which parts of the case against Mrs MacPhail were dismissed because, since her November 2016 divorce, she no longer owns the house.

Advertisement

The Gueterbocks are seeking an injunction requiring the partial filling in of the basement and repositioning of the house wall against Mr MacPhail alone.

However, they continue to sue both Mr and Mrs MacPhail for damages for trespass from the date that the work started until the date she ceased to own it.

None of the neighbours were present for the hearing and the case itself will be heard by a judge at a later date.
